abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel has proposed curbs on executive pay for companies expecting to tap a 115 billion euro ($145 billion) German liquidity fund.
snippet: Chancellor Angela Merkel has proposed curbs on executive pay for companies expecting to tap a 115 billion euro ($145 billion) German liquidity fund.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel, left, has proposed curbs on executive pay for companies expecting to tap a 115 billion euro ($145 billion) German liquidity fund. The three parties that form Mrs. Merkel’s coalition government agreed in Berlin on Wednesday night that executive compensation should be made more transparent and geared to a company’s long-term interests rather than short-term results. The measures would be aimed at all public companies, not just banks. Mrs. Merkel’s coalition, facing Sept. 27 national elections, is taking steps beyond those in Britain and the United States.

headline.main: Germany: Executive Pay May Be Curbed
headline.print_headline: GERMANY: EXECUTIVE PAY MAY BE CURBED

abstract: Mattel, the world’s biggest toymaker, has opened its first store dedicated to sales of its Barbie dolls and accessories in a six-story building in Shanghai.
snippet: Mattel, the world’s biggest toymaker, has opened its first store dedicated to sales of its Barbie dolls and accessories in a six-story building in Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: Mattel, the world’s biggest toymaker, has opened its first store dedicated to sales of its Barbie dolls and accessories in a six-story building in Shanghai. Mattel is looking to China for growth after fourth-quarter profit fell 46 percent. The new Barbie store will be the first of a global chain as the company expands abroad, said Richard Dickson, Mattel’s senior vice president. To win fans in China, Barbie will have to take on established brands like Japan’s Hello Kitty, from the Sanrio Company, said Paul French, founder of the market research company Access Asia in Shanghai.

headline.main: China: First All-Barbie Store Opens
headline.print_headline: CHINA: FIRST ALL-BARBIE STORE OPENS

abstract: In its survey of Eastern Europe, the Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies found that there had not been a sudden stop in international financial flows across the whole region.
snippet: In its survey of Eastern Europe, the Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies found that there had not been a sudden stop in international financial flows across the whole region.
lead_paragraph: In its survey of Eastern Europe, the Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies found that there had not been a sudden stop in international financial flows across the whole region. So far, only a few countries, including Hungary, Latvia and Ukraine have been seriously hurt, it said. Those countries, as well as Estonia, Hungary, Latvia and Lithuania, are expected to suffer a significant fall in economic growth leading to a recession, it said, while economies of the Czech Republic, Poland, Slovenia and Slovakia may stagnate but not necessarily slip into recession.

headline.main: Austria: Report on Eastern Europe
headline.print_headline: AUSTRIA: REPORT ON EASTERN EUROPE

abstract: Nobody knows for sure whether G.E. is in trouble — not even the bears who are shouting it from the rafters.

lead_paragraph: I had no idea that this was going to be hell week for General Electric when I decided to write about it. What spurred my column this week was the company’s decision to cut its dividend last Friday by 66 percent. But hell week it certainly was. Two analysts at a small firm came out with a brutal report essentially predicting the kind of downward spiral that has so badly damaged other big firms, like Citi and Bank of America. Other bears circled. Credit default spreads widened. The stock sank. The chief financial officer went on CNBC to defend the company. And on and on it went, a dance we’ve seen again and again — usually with bad results.

headline.main: Is General Electric Next?

abstract: An article on Feb. 22 about the austerity of Japanese consumers, a legacy of the economic malaise that plagued Japan from the 1990s until the early 2000s, referred incorrectly to a residential area known as Nakano, the home of one frugal Japanese family whose members talked about their lives. It is part of the city of Tokyo, not a suburb. The article also misspelled, in some editions, part of the name of a research group whose economist, Hideo Kumano, said Japan’s economy may once again be entering a prolonged malaise. It is Dai-ichi Life Research Institute (not Dai-chi).

snippet: A recent report suggests “cybersquatting” -- the practice of maliciously snapping up a Web site with someone else’s trademark in its domain name -- is increasingly popular.
lead_paragraph: “Cybersquatting,” the practice of maliciously snapping up a Web site with someone else’s trademark in its domain name, is illegal in the United States. It is also an easy way to make money; a cybersquatter can impersonate the trademark’s owner, sell ad space to the victim’s competitors, or extort a payment in return for turning over the Web site.

abstract: Revisiting a newly timely tune, “Bear Market Blues.”
snippet: Revisiting a newly timely tune, “Bear Market Blues.”
lead_paragraph: Apparently, when I wrote my first book, “A Piece of the Action,” in 1994, I mentioned in passing a song entitled “Bull Market High.” (Honestly, I can’t remember doing so.) Today, out of the blue, I got an e-mail message from one Joe Fisher, who described himself to me as a former broker with Dean Witter and L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin in the 1980s (“and,” he notes, “reveled in the rising market and I.P.O. craze”). He is also a songwriter in San Francisco, and he turns out to have written “Bull Market High” — as well as two companion pieces, “Bear Market Blues” and “Unemployment.” He thought I would enjoy listening to “Bear Market Blues” given that we’re in, well, a bear market. Somewhat to my surprise, I did. I’ll bet you will, too. Here’s the link. Love that chromatic harmonica, the world’s most underrated instrument.

headline.main: Sing Your Troubles Away

This somewhat dated page of Newsday constructors tells us that Mr. Wolfe is a veterinarian, a long-distance runner and a writer of poetry, screenplays and novels. Puzzle people have such interesting backgrounds. I still remember his clue “Tick source” from last year. The answer is here. And speaking of past puzzles, “Washington is just above it” reminded me of Patrick Blindauer’s rectangular puzzle from the fall (Across Lite, Solution.)

abstract: Do you seek out or avoid the explanation answer?
snippet: Do you seek out or avoid the explanation answer?
lead_paragraph: Sometimes an early-week crossword has an explanation clue that ties it all together. I fill in the grid in more or less random order, and I happened to find 62 Across early on: “They can be found in 20- and 55-Across and 10- and 26-Down.” What’s your strategy when you discover a “they can be found” clue? I used to view it as the key and tackle that section first, knowing it would make the rest of the puzzle easier. Now, I purposefully ignore such corners until the other theme answers have been filled in, giving myself a chance to suss out the common thread myself. It’s a bonus puzzle you can choose to accept or not.

headline.main: They Can Be Found

abstract: A strike by Petrobras workers cut output at refineries in Brazil and also temporarily halted crude production of 60,000 barrels a day and 1.4 million cubic meters of natural gas, union officials said.
snippet: A strike by Petrobras workers cut output at refineries in Brazil and also temporarily halted crude production of 60,000 barrels a day and 1.4 million cubic meters of natural gas, union officials said.
lead_paragraph: A strike by Petrobras workers cut output at refineries in Brazil and also temporarily halted crude production of 60,000 barrels a day and 1.4 million cubic meters of natural gas, union officials said. The walkout over profit-sharing and safety issues may force the company to cut output from about 40 percent of the Campos Basin, Brazil’s main producing region, as well as fields in Brazil’s northeast and Amazon regions, said Marluzio Ferreira, spokesman for the national oil workers federation. Work was also disrupted at 11 refineries, he said. The union says Petrobras has refused requests to improve safety measures, and that 165 employees have been killed since 2002. The union also says the company has sought to cut revenue and profit sharing. Petrobras, which is adding workers, is aiming to reduce costs as oil prices fall and it embarks on a $174.4 billion five-year investment plan. Petrobras said in a statement on its Web site that all its units were operating normally during the strike.

headline.main: Brazil: Petrobras Strike Impact
headline.print_headline: Brazil: Petrobras Strike Impact

abstract: Time Warner Said It Would Pay $241.5. Million For a 31 Percent Stake In Central European Media Enterprises, the Broadcast Company Founded By the Cosmetics Heir Ronald S. Lauder.
snippet: Time Warner Said It Would Pay $241.5. Million For a 31 Percent Stake In Central European Media Enterprises, the Broadcast Company Founded By the Cosmetics Heir Ronald S. Lauder.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner said it would pay $241.5 million for a 31 percent stake in Central European Media Enterprises, the broadcast company founded by the cosmetics heir Ronald S. Lauder, left. The company also said its Warner Brothers unit has formed a partnership with the company to start TV channels in Central and Eastern Europe. Central European Media Enterprises, which is based in Bermuda, operates in Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine. Central European Media said separately that it expected $135 million to $145 million in sales for the first quarter, compared with $223 million in the year-ago quarter. That fell well below the average analyst estimate of $167.2 million, according to Thomson Reuters.

headline.main: Time Warner Buys Stake in Central European Media Enterprises

lead_paragraph: ING Group has asked 1,200 workers, including its 200 “top employees,” to return last year’s bonuses. The bank also deferred 2009 variable cash compensation for all workers until a new policy is established next year, it said in a message to employees and obtained by Bloomberg News. “Given the continuing public scrutiny of variable pay practices in our industry, ING is moving to align its variable compensation practices with the new reality,” it said. ING received a 10 billion euro ($13.5 billion) bailout from its government in October.

abstract: Japan’s exports plunged by a record in February as deepening recessions in the United States and Europe sapped demand for the country’s cars and electronics.
snippet: Japan’s exports plunged by a record in February as deepening recessions in the United States and Europe sapped demand for the country’s cars and electronics.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s exports plunged by a record in February as deepening recessions in the United States and Europe sapped demand for the country’s cars and electronics. Overseas shipments plummeted 49.4 percent from a year earlier, the sharpest decline since at least 1980, when the government started to keep comparable data, the Finance Ministry said in Tokyo. Economists predicted a 47.6 percent drop. “There’s been a structural shock to the manufacturing sector,” said Hiroshi Shiraishi, an economist at BNP Paribas in Tokyo. “So yes, the government can create demand temporarily, but that can’t fill the export gap forever.” Japan’s gross domestic product shrank an annualized 12.1 percent last quarter, the biggest contraction among the world’s advanced economies and the country’s sharpest decline since the 1974 oil crisis. Japan has become more reliant on exports in the last decade, making it especially vulnerable to changes in global commerce. During Japan’s expansion of 2002 to 2007, exports as a portion of gross domestic product rose to 15.6 percent, from 10.4 percent.

headline.main: Japan: Exports Plunge Almost 50%
headline.print_headline: Japan: Exports Plunge Almost 50%

abstract: NYSE Euronext, which operates stock exchanges in Amsterdam, Brussels, Lisbon and Paris, said it would cut fees on its European markets by about 20 percent.
snippet: NYSE Euronext, which operates stock exchanges in Amsterdam, Brussels, Lisbon and Paris, said it would cut fees on its European markets by about 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: NYSE Euronext, which operates stock exchanges in Amsterdam, Brussels, Lisbon and Paris, said it would cut fees on its European markets by about 20 percent as it fights increasing competition in the region. Clients will be charged for each executed order on NYSE Euronext’s European stock markets rather than for each trade, the company said in a statement. For NYSE Arca Europe, its alternative trading system, the exchange will charge 0.15 basis points for all trades and provide volume incentives. A basis point is 0.01 percentage point. NYSE Euronext and other European exchanges are trying to fend off multilateral trading facilities that are seeking to gain market share by offering cheaper trades and faster technology. NYSE Euronext has lost about 20 percent of its market share in Europe for stocks listed on the benchmark CAC 40 index in Paris.

headline.main: Trading Fees Cut for Stock Exchanges
headline.print_headline: Trading Fees Cut for Stock Exchanges

lead_paragraph: Autoliv, the world’s largest maker of air bags for cars, said it had cut 3,000 jobs in the first two months of the year, eliminating 2,600 permanent and 400 temporary positions. It said it had reduced its total number of employees by 20 percent, or 9,000 jobs, since June. In a separate statement, the company said it would raise $350 million from a common share and equity unit offering. Autoliv, which is based in Stockholm, said it would offer $200 million in common stock and $150 million in the form of equity units in underwritten registered public offerings in the United States.

abstract: An article on Monday about a dispute between Warner Music and YouTube over payment for Warner’s copyrighted videos referred incorrectly to a court ruling over copyright of the Zapruder film, the home movie that captured the Kennedy assassination. A federal judge ruled that Time Inc., which had bought the film, held a valid copyright; he did not deny that it could be a copyrighted work. (The judge also ruled that a book publisher’s use of frames from the film, which was the basis of Time’s copyright-infringement lawsuit, was a “fair use” because of significant public interest in the film.)
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about a dispute between Warner Music and YouTube over payment for Warner’s copyrighted videos referred incorrectly to a court ruling over copyright of the Zapruder film, the home movie that captured the Kennedy assassination. abstract: Greece fined Citigroup $1.3 million, accusing it of misleading investors in the sale of a string of Lehman Brothers financial products.
snippet: Greece fined Citigroup $1.3 million, accusing it of misleading investors in the sale of a string of Lehman Brothers financial products.
lead_paragraph: Greece fined Citigroup $1.3 million, accusing it of misleading investors in the sale of a string of Lehman Brothers financial products. The fine, issued by the country’s development ministry, comes after a class-action suit filed this year by 92 Greek private investors who had placed 120 million euros ($159 million) in deals with Lehman Brothers through Citigroup. The products offered to Citibank investors called for zero-risk secured capital investment plans. It remains unclear whether other banks in Greece will be fined for offering similar plans before Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy last year.

headline.main: Greece: Citi Fined in Lehman Case
headline.print_headline: Greece: Citi Fined In Lehman Case

abstract: Though it remains one of the lower-rated series on network television, the widely praised NBC drama “Friday Night Lights” won yet another reprieve from cancellation this week, and now will have at least two more seasons of 13 episodes each. The deal almost didn’t happen, mainly over the price of the license fee for DirecTV.

abstract: Preliminary studies of a blockbuster drug from Roche’s Genentech unit are strong enough to speed its approval for brain cancer, federal cancer experts said.
snippet: Preliminary studies of a blockbuster drug from Roche’s Genentech unit are strong enough to speed its approval for brain cancer, federal cancer experts said.
lead_paragraph: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration unanimously recommended Tuesday that Genentech’s drug Avastin be approved as a treatment for a deadly form of brain cancer, despite the F.D.A.’s own staff reviewers’ saying there was a lack of compelling evidence that the drug worked for that use.

headline.main: F.D.A. Panel Supports Avastin to Treat Brain Tumor
